thread.title: Nease puts end to St. Augustine's 11-year district reign with comeback win in overtime
thread.title_full: Nease puts end to St. Augustine's 11-year district reign with comeback win in overtime

author: Clayton Freeman
title: Nease puts end to St. Augustine's 11-year district reign with comeback win in overtime
text:
Nease puts end to St. Augustine's 11-year district reign with comeback win in overtime Panthers win in OT, snap Yellow Jackets' 50-game district streak 
By Clayton Freeman Sat, Oct 24, 2015 @ 3:05 am | updated Sat, Oct 24, 2015 @ 8:52 am Back Photo: 1 of 6 Next GARY MCCULLOUGH/CORRESPONDENT Nease's Kendric Harris (3) crosses the goal line for a touchdown against St. Augustine during the first half Friday at Nease High School. The Panthers won in overtime. Gary McCullough For the Times-Union Back Photo: 2 of 6 Next GARY MCCULLOUGH/CORRESPONDENT Gary McCullough For the Times-Union St. Augustine's Jacob Jones reaches for and recovers a fumbled Nease snap during the first quarter Friday. Back Photo: 3 of 6 Next GARY MCCULLOUGH/CORRESPONDENT GARY MCCULLOUGH/CORRESPONDENT Nease's Leighton Alley (7) throws a pass against St. Augustine during the 1st half of high school football action at Nease High School in Ponte Vedra, Fla., on Friday, October 23, 2015. Back Photo: 4 of 6 Next GARY MCCULLOUGH/CORRESPONDENT GARY MCCULLOUGH/CORRESPONDENT St. Augustine's Donald Sapp (6) catches a pass and scores a touchdown on their first play from scrimmage against Nease during the 1st quarter of high school football action at Nease High School in Ponte Vedra, Fla., on Friday, October 23, 2015. Back Photo: 5 of 6 Next GARY MCCULLOUGH/CORRESPONDENT GARY MCCULLOUGH/CORRESPONDENT St. Augustine's Jacob Jones (8) reaches for and recovers a fumbled Nease snap during the 1st quarter of high school football action at Nease High School in Ponte Vedra, Fla., on Friday, October 23, 2015. Back Photo: 6 of 6 Next GARY MCCULLOUGH/CORRESPONDENT GARY MCCULLOUGH/CORRESPONDENT St. Augustine's Cole Northrup (11) throws a pass against Nease during the 1st half of high school football action at Nease High School in Ponte Vedra, Fla., on Friday, October 23, 2015. 
The streaks are dead. 
St. Augustine’s 11 consecutive district titles. The Yellow Jackets’ seven straight victories over Nease. Their 50 consecutive wins in district play, a run that dated to Oct. 30, 2003. 
Nease is celebrating a district championship thanks to a shoeless quarterback, an untested receiver and an unyielding spirit. 
Leighton Alley’s touchdown pass to Mikey Cotter in overtime capped a stunning comeback and lifted the host Panthers to an unforgettable 23-20 victory over county rival St. Augustine in District 4-6A. 
After the Yellow Jackets’ Bradley Meeks kicked a 30-yard field goal on the first possession of overtime, Alley found Cotter in the flat and the senior receiver lunged for the pylon to score the first touchdown of his high school career. 
“That kid just played so hard all year,” Nease coach Tim Krause said. “He blocks, he’s a great teammate, and to be able to make a play like that is just phenomenal.” 
With four minutes to go, that finish seemed impossible. 
St. Augustine took a 17-7 lead on a Jahquise Russell 15-yard run, leaving the Panthers (6-2, 3-0) in a 10-point hole and pinned back at their own 20. 
Alley didn’t lose heart. 
The junior quarterback, playing for part of the drive with only one shoe, marched Nease up the field, capping the possession with a 1-yard sneak. 
St. Augustine’s EJ Eldridge recovered an onside kick, but the Yellow Jackets failed to run out the clock as Nease used its timeouts and then forced Russell out of bounds on third down, stopping the clock. 
Alley then took over at his own 23, advancing upfield with key passes to Reidar Hubbard and Zach Sheffer before the drive stalled inside the Jackets’ 5. Michael Leisle kicked the field goal to force overtime. 
“I just knew our defense would take them three-and-out,” Alley said. “Once they gave us a shot, we knew we’d make the most of it.” 
The Yellow Jackets (7-1, 2-1) went ahead early after a miscue when Alley bobbled a snap and St. Augustine defensive end Jacob Jones recovered at the Nease 20. On the next snap, Donald Sapp caught a 20-yard strike to the corner from junior Cole Northrup. 
One play. One score. That start could have demoralized the Panthers, who had lost their previous two games against St. Augustine by a combined 100-0. 
It didn’t. 
“We had our backs against the wall early and the kids just kept playing, kept fighting,” Krause said. “They did some crazy things that I don’t think they thought they were capable of.” 
The durable frame of Kendric Harris carried Nease back into the contest, hitting the line again and again for steady chunks of yardage. 
Nease tied the score in the second quarter when a two-yard Harris plunge capped an 80-yard marathon drive that included four conversions on third and fourth down. 
Jordan Willis and Tyric Reid led a sterling defensive effort for Nease. St. Augustine’s Connor Evans tallied 17 tackles. 
The Panthers can make their playoff reservations for the first time since 2008. For today, they’re savoring the moment. 
“That’s everyone’s dream. ... Bartram came close, but we wanted them undefeated. We wanted them not to lose a county game. We wanted to be the ones to stop the streak,” Alley said.
